1_12rMePjZCdJVqTaAYf3Dg3fk3bYFfTPDsP.body:
> [technoshaman777](#comment_1_1DTUNWykvXLbxZud5a8gJsq7DxmxcGk52E): Not working for me. Which browser should I be using? I was wondering if someone would integrate WT with Zeronet. Can anyone confirm that WebRTC does not leak IP?

Hi there. User isn't seeding video, or codec is wrong. Try my webseeded videos.. cheers!

> [technoshaman777](#comment_1_1DTUNWykvXLbxZud5a8gJsq7DxmxcGk52E): Not working for me. Which browser should I be using? I was wondering if someone would integrate WT with Zeronet. Can anyone confirm that WebRTC does not leak IP?

WebRTC will only leak your IP if you program it to do so. WebTorrent isn't programmed in order to leak your IP, obviously.. though theoretically, somebody could modify their local Javascript in order to leak all of the IP addresses of peers that are seeding/downloading a torrent. Not 100% sure about this however, as it hasn't been tested.

This alone is no reason to dismiss WebTorrent altogether, as it is a powerful and versatile tool that will save time and bring torrenting to the mainstream. WebRTC is open source, and security is obviously a major concern to many users, so there's a lot of people working on a fix for this problem right now. I will post updates on this issue in the News thread, so stay tuned!

9_16w7UuJAHbt8YBa8zxHS7UFk9mq8Q5DpE4.body:
> [technoshaman777](#comment_3_1DTUNWykvXLbxZud5a8gJsq7DxmxcGk52E): KopyKate,  I was able to view your webseeded videos, but I question why we have to host our files on a cloud service first. Doesn't that kind of reverse engineer the tech so that we are back to just streaming from one source? That also seems to lower personal security because a dropbox account can be flagged and banned. Please fill me in, if I'm wrong.

The WebSeed option is only for people who are too lazy to seed, or cannot seed but still want the torrent to be available for others to seed. I was just tired of videos not playing, that's all. ;)

> [technoshaman777](#comment_2_1DTUNWykvXLbxZud5a8gJsq7DxmxcGk52E): Thanks for the info KopyKate. For what it's worth, WebTorrent posts this info on their FAQ:
> "Does WebTorrent leak your IP address when using a VPN? I heard that WebRTC leaks your IP address.
> No.
> WebRTC data channels do not allow a website to discover your public IP address when there is a VPN in use. The WebRTC discovery process will just find your VPN's IP address and the local network IP address.
> Local IP addresses (e.g. 10.x.x.x or 192.168.x.x) can potentially be used to "fingerprint" your browser and identify across different sites that you visit, like a third-party tracking cookie. However, this is a separate issue than exposing your real public IP address, and it's worth noting that the browser already provides hundreds of vectors for fingerprinting you (e.g. your installed fonts, screen resolution, browser window size, OS version, language, etc.).
> If you have a VPN enabled, then WebRTC data channels will not connect to peers using your true public IP address, nor will it be reveled to the JavaScript running on the webpage.
> At one point in time, WebRTC did have an issue where it would allow a website to discover your true public IP address, but this was fixed a long time ago. This unfortunate misinformation keeps bouncing around the internet.
> There's now a spec that defines exactly which IP addresses are exposed with WebRTC. If you're interested in further reading, you can read the IP handling spec for yourself."

Thanks for that info, btw. Who would have known that the answer was in the Webtorrent faq? Geez.. just shoot me now. lol

2_1DTUNWykvXLbxZud5a8gJsq7DxmxcGk52E.body:

>  I uploaded this new one and it works. You can get rid of the other copy that did not work. It would be nice if you could provide an edit option for videos that we have personally uploaded. By the way, how hard is it to embed the ability to Chromecast these videos? Of course, it would also be nice if we could figure out how to integrate the features of Plex media center to pull cover art and metadata down as well. I'm not a coder or web developer, so I'm just hopeing someone can make it happen!

Thanks, just downloaded it. I'm seeding this video too now, I'll be seeding many others too. I might even webseed this particular one, especially since it's fair use.
 
Just so you know, ALL videos on KopyKate constitute fair use, that includes Rihanna's music.. and Metallica's. ;)

32_16w7UuJAHbt8YBa8zxHS7UFk9mq8Q5DpE4.body:
> [modular](#comment_1_1A3fAocj6wZCCweR6LgWmbTTaht4jSgGti): I'm guessing it won't be always this slow?

Depends on your computer specs and internet connection speed. This is a webseed, so it should max out its speed.

I currently have 2.50MB/s download. My internet connection speed is 45 Mbps Download and 2Mbps Upload. I have 2GHz dual core and 4GB RAM as well as a 500MB Nvidia graphics card. The video above plays smoothly with no dropped frames.

Keep in mind that this is a 720p video too. Normally on YouTube the video player automatically switches to a lower resolution if it has trouble playing at a normal speed. Then again, YouTube stores multiple copies of its videos with different resolutions on its servers .. I'd have to manually encode a 480p and a 240p version for this video for users with slow connections, which should solve the problem I guess.

5_114DPuy8FMBFTX7zSd4v54iKkRG6qVVx7P.body:
> [ibnussabeel](#comment_1_114DPuy8FMBFTX7zSd4v54iKkRG6qVVx7P): Bother. The original magnet link was taken from Play on Zeronet and downloaded to WebTorrent which works fine when played in app. But, once WebTorrent's magnet link is downloaded here on KopyKate only the first (and shortest) MP4 file plays even though it downloads the whole 1.31GB. I was trying to get the same number of peers on Play to show on KopyKate. Did not happen. But file seems to download much quicker: this may just be perception or luck. No criticism of KopyKate intended. Thank you for your good work.

Criticism is very much welcome and needed.

WebTorrent Desktop uses VLC media player in order to play media that is being downloaded to the computer. 

However, on the browser, you need to have your videos especially encoded for browser playback (this is why videos that have been downloaded from YouTube, will play perfectly on here). On YouTube, all of this is done automatically on your behalf on their servers .. which is why there is a delay after uploading (Processing your video ... 95%...)

That's when YouTube digests your video into a lighter format that goes easy on most devices. This format uses H.264 video and AAC audio, with an average bitrate of 1mbps or so. Most of the times when you watch a video, it also switches you into 480p mode (which is a resolution of about 720x480).

WebTorrent also cannot harness peers from BitTorrent clients. They're both incompatible. WebTorrent uses WebRTC .. bittorrent uses UDP/TCP

Having said that.. I'll be encoding and seeding a lot more videos in future. Problem I have right now is that I'm using a 12 year old laptop for encoding AND seeding .. and a lot of the time this thing just crashes and dies on me .. which stops all the torrents from seeding.

Once I get a good quad core desktop with 3.0ghz 8GB ram with a good NVIDIA graphics card, I could be pumping out 20 movies a day. Should get that organized by January. ;)
